text.headline:
Artificial Intelligence
1950 - 2014
text.text: Artificial Intelligence is a system created to replicate human intelligence and problem-solving abilities. They make them by taking data and processing them to help them learn from past mistakes in order to improve.

media.caption: 1936: Alan Turing & The Turing Machine - Pivotal Moments

text.headline: Alan Turing
text.text: Published a book ‘Computer Machinery and Intelligence’ that considers the question ‘Can machines think?’. He also made the ‘Turing Test’ also known as the ‘Imitation Game’ in which an interrogator attempts to distinguish if they’re talking to a human or machine.

media.caption: Professor’s perceptron paved the way for AI – 60 years too soon

text.headline: Frank Rosenblatt
text.text: Perceptron, the first ever feedforward neural network that could learn from data invented by Frank Rosenblatt. This was the first concrete step that laid the foundation for modern machine learning.

media.caption: The games that helped AI evolve

text.headline: Arthur Samuel
text.text: The term ‘Machine Learning’ was coined by Arthur Samuel in 1959 where he made a checker-playing program that improved through self play. His program’s decision-making abilities were due to methods like alpha-beta pruning, scoring functions, and ‘rote learning’ where the machine stored movesets for future reference.

media.caption: Geoffrey Hinton, Godfather of AI, Warns: These Jobs Will Vanish, But A Few Stand Strong

text.headline: Geoffrey Hinton
text.text: The ‘Godfather of AI’ and internationally renowned as a pioneer in the field of deep learning. He was one of the researchers who introduced and first to use 'Backpropagation' algorithm for learning word embeddings.

media.caption: To Build Truly Intelligent Machines, Teach Them Cause and Effect

text.headline: Judea Pearl
text.text: Credited with the invention of a mathematical formalism that defines complex probability models called the ‘Bayesian Networks’. It became an important tool that revolutionized other branches of engineering and natural sciences.

media.caption: Vladimir Vapnik, Winner of the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award in ICT (IMAGE)

text.headline: Vladimir Vapnik
text.text: Co-developer of a machine learning called the ‘Support Vector’ that’s used to solve pattern recognition and regression estimation problems. His current research has shaped statistical learning theory.

text.headline: Yann LeCun
text.text: Created LeNet-5, a neural network design for character recognition in both handwriting and machine printing and is frequently used as the first step in teaching Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). This demonstrated CNN’s effectiveness for image recognition as well as introducing key concepts such as convolution, pooling, and hierarchical feature extraction.

media.caption: Yoshua Bengio joins hundreds of signatories in open letter pleading for safer AI systems

text.headline: Yoshua Bengio
text.text: A major contribution of Yoshua Bengio is his paper ‘A Neural Probabilistic Language Model’, advanced research in deep learning and representation learning. Furthermore, Bengio’s group improved the performance of machine learning translation systems by combining neural word embeddings with attention mechanisms.

media.caption: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li: ‘I’m more concerned about the risks that are here and now’

text.headline: Fei-Fei Li
text.text: ImageNet, a visual database designed for visual object recognition software research to train algorithms. This provided a wide variety of data to train machine learning models effectively.

media.caption: Ian Goodfellow A Man, A Plan, A GAN

text.headline: Ian Goodfellow
text.text: Introduced Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) that enabled researchers to create realistic-looking computer-generated photos of people’s faces. This paved the way for Goodfellow’s career in Apple where he’s the director of machine learning.
